awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to William A. Johnson is "Model Theory of Fields". The host institution for the fellowship is Fudan University, Shanghai China, and the sponsoring scientist is Meng Chen.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
I completed a two-year long postdoctoral position in the mathematics department at Fudan University, in Shanghai, China.  My research was in mathematical logic, which uses the tools of abstract mathematics to understand logic.  More specifically, I carried out several projects in the subject of model theory, which seeks to understand logical systems through mathematical structures that can serve as "models" of the logical system.  For example, one such logical system is Euclidean geometry--the sort of geometry taught in high-school.  The intended "model" of geometry is the physical world, with its points, lines, and planes.  In the 1800's, the mathematician Eugenio Beltrami showed that by interpreting "points", "lines", and "planes" in a different way, one could get an alternate "model" of geometry.  This model gave new insight into what can and cannot be proved in geometry.  That is, it helped mathematicians to better understand the logic of geometry.

 

During my postdoctoral position, I worked on three projects related to the model theory of fields.  A "field" is a model of algebra, analogous to how Beltrami's model is a model of geometry.  A "field" is a set of "numbers" that can be "added", "multiplied", "subtracted", and "divided", in ways that obey the laws of algebra.  Fields are pervasive throughout modern mathematics.  My first project involved the problem of classifying fields that have a technical property called "NIP".  This problem is a major area of research in model theory, and I accomplished the goal of classifying the NIP fields that are "finite dimensional" in a certain technical sense (finite dp-rank).  I wrote six papers on the topic, of which the first has been published.  My research in this area was well-received by my colleagues, and was the subject of reading groups at UCLA and at the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute in Berkeley.

 

My second project involved a study of how properties of finite structures can transfer to infinite structures.  My third project was an analysis of the logical properties of fields with multiple valuations.  (Valuations are a certain mathematical concept arising in algebra and number theory.  Number theorists use valuations to better understand prime numbers.)  I made significant progress on my second and third projects.  Aside from these three projects, I also began work on a new collaboration with Erik Walsberg, Jinhe Ye, and Minh Tran.  Our project offered new insights into the theory of fields.  Altogether, the research carried out during my postdoctoral position was a substantial contribution to the development of model theory.

 

Prior to the start of the pandemic, I attended several conferences and workshops where I presented my research and communicated with other mathematicians.  In 2019, I spent a couple weeks in Nanjing, China at a conference in mathematical logic, where I presented my research.  This gave me a chance to communicate with people in other branches of mathematical logic, such as set theory and recursion theory.  Later in the year, I attended a conference in Muenster, Germany on the model theory of fields with valuations.  This gave me a chance to communicate with other researchers around the world working on closely related topics.  Additionally, I attended a model theory conference in Toronto, Canada, and gave a talk at a mathematical logic conference in Chongqing, China.

 

Aside from accomplishing most of my research goals, I believe I helped serve as a bridge between groups of people that might not otherwise interact.  At Fudan University (and in much of China more generally), mathematical logicians are grouped with philosophers rather than mathematicians.  By being in the mathematics department, I was able to expose mathematicians to mathematical logic.  For example, I taught a one-week summer school course on mathematical logic to mathematics students at Fudan.  Additionally, the mathematical logic community in China has few model theorists (there are only three or four of us, in a country of 1.4 billion people), so I was able to help bring model theory to China.  For example, I taught a one-week summer school course on technical areas in model theory to philosophy students at Fudan.  (Following my postdoc, I continued this work by becoming a full-time faculty member of the philosophy department, and teaching model theory to philosophy students).  Additionally, I was able to serve as a bridge by being one of few foreign mathematicians in China, especially once the pandemic began.  In 2020, I participated in the annual conference of the Chinese Mathematical Society in Shijiazhuang, and was, as far as I can tell, the only foreigner in attendance.
